book.title: The Great Gatsby
book.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
book.preface: The Great Gatsby, F. Scott Fitzgerald's third book, stands as the supreme achievement of his career. This exemplary novel of the Jazz Age has been acclaimed by generations of readers.

chapter.title: Chapter 1
chapter.summary: A mysterious millionaire, Jay Gatsby, throws extravagant parties in the hopes of rekindling his romance with Daisy Buchanan.

section.content: Gatsby's lavish parties are the talk of the town, but his motives remain enigmatic.
Nick Carraway, the narrator, becomes entangled in the lives of Gatsby and the Buchanans, leading to tragic consequences.

chapter.title: Chapter 2
chapter.summary: Gatsby's past and his obsession with Daisy are revealed, shedding light on his character.

section.content: Flashbacks unveil Gatsby's humble origins and his transformation into a wealthy socialite.
Gatsby's single-minded pursuit of Daisy is driven by his desire to relive the past.

book.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
book.author: Harper Lee
book.preface: Harper Lee's Pulitzer Prize-winning masterwork of honor and injustice in the deep Southâ€”and the heroism of one man in the face of blind and violent hatred.

chapter.title: Chapter 1
chapter.summary: Scout Finch, her brother Jem, and their father Atticus are introduced in the town of Maycomb, Alabama.

section.content: The children befriend Dill Harris and become fascinated with their reclusive neighbor, Boo Radley.
Atticus Finch, a lawyer, defends a black man, Tom Robinson, accused of raping a white woman, facing prejudice and hostility.

chapter.title: Chapter 2
chapter.summary: The trial of Tom Robinson unfolds, revealing the deep-seated racism and injustice in Maycomb.

section.content: Despite overwhelming evidence of Tom's innocence, the all-white jury convicts him, leading to tragedy.
